lgcpspatial.heading moduleÔÉÅ

heading.py: Subroutines used in example 5: heading dependence.

lgcpspatial.heading.smoothed_heading_angle(px, py, Fs=50.0, Fl=2.0)[source]ÔÉÅ

Calculate smoothed estimate of heading from position data.

On a standard Cartesian plane, with the y axis increasing from bottom to top, and the x axis increasing from left to right, the heading angles are as follows:

  • 0 : rightwards (eastwards)

  • ¬ΩœÄ : upwards (northwards)

  • œÄ : leftwards (westwards)

  • 3œÄ/2: downwards (southwards)

Parameters

  • px (float32) ‚Äì List of animal‚Äôs location, x-coordinate

  • py (float32) ‚Äì List of animal‚Äôs location, y-coordinate

  • Fs (float) ‚Äì Sampling rate of (px,py) position data

  • Fl (float) ‚Äì Low-pass cutoff frequency in Hz

Returns

heading_angle ‚Äì Heading angle based on the low-pass derivative of position.

Return type

float32

lgcpspatial.heading.get_peaks_at_heading_angles(data, model, heading_angles, threshold=10.0, Fs=50.0, Fl=2.0)[source]ÔÉÅ

Check for location shifts based on heading. Re-weight data based on cosine similarity to target heading angle.

Parameters

  • data (object) ‚Äì

    Any object with the following attributes:
    L: float

    Size of LxL spatial grid for binned data.

    n: np.float32

    Length L¬≤ array of visits to each bin.

    y: np.float32

    Length L¬≤ array of spikes at each bin.

    prior_mean: np.float32

    Shape L√óL or L¬≤ array containing the prior mean-log-rate. This should background rate variations unrelated to the grid structure

    lograte_guess: float32 array

    Shape L√óL or L¬≤ array with an initial guess for log rate. This should be expressed as a deviation from prior_mean.

    arena.hull:

    Convex Hull object describing the arena perimeter

  • model (lgcpspatial.DiagonalFourierLowrank) ‚Äì parent model instance (fitted model without heading filtering)

  • heading_angles (np.float32 array) ‚Äì List of heading angles to check. Westward is 0 degrees, then rotates counterclockwise through southward, eastward, northward.

  • threshold (float) ‚Äì Percentile peaks must be above to be retained. Should be in [0,100).

Returns

peaks ‚Äì List of 2√óNPEAKS float32 arrays containing (x,y) locations of peaks at each of the angles specified by the list heading_angles.

Return type

list

lgcpspatial.heading.match_peaks(peaks, maxd)[source]ÔÉÅ

Matching algorithm:

  • Assume q come from an array of angles on [0,2pi)

  • Get distances between all adjacent angles

  • Build directed graph joining fields of adjacent angles

  • Greedy approach

    • If you‚Äôre my closest match, and I‚Äôm yours, pair up.

    • Repeat until no more edges closer than maxd

Parameters

  • peaks (list) ‚Äì Length NANGLES list of 2√óNPEAKS float32 arrays with (x,y) locations of peaks at each heading angle

  • maxd ‚Äì The maximum distance between peaks allowed when connecting them

Returns

edges ‚Äì Length NANGLES list of edge sets for each pair of headings. Each list entry is a 2√óNEDGES int32 array. This contains pairs of indecies (a,b). For edge set i, index a is the index into peaks[i] (edge source) and index b is the index into peaks[(i+1)%NœÜ] (edge target).

Return type

list

lgcpspatial.heading.pair_points(z1, z2, connection_radius)[source]ÔÉÅ

Greedily associate nearest-neighbors between two point sets z1 and z2, limiting matches to points closer than connection_radius apart. 2D points are encoded as complex numbers.

Parameters

  • z1 (iterable) ‚Äì iterable of 2D points encoded as complex numbers

  • z2 (iterable) ‚Äì iterable of 2D points encoded as complex numbers

  • connection_radius (float) ‚Äì Maximum radius at which to allow connections.

Returns

  • index1 (int32) ‚Äì index into z1 of paired points

  • index2 (int32) ‚Äì index into z2 of paired points

lgcpspatial.heading.extract_as_paths(peaks, edges)[source]ÔÉÅ

Convert tracked (peaks,edges) to a list of 2D paths.

Parameters

  • peaks (list) ‚Äì Length NANGLES list of 2xNPEAKS np.float32 arrays containing (rx,ry) peak locations at a list of heading angles, as returned by get_peaks_at_heading_angles().

  • edges (list) ‚Äì Length NANGLES list of edge sets for each pair of headings, as returned by match_peaks or link_peaks(). Each list entry is a 2√óNEDGES int32 array. This contains pairs of indecies (a,b). For edge set i, index a is the index into peaks[i] (edge source) and index b is the index into peaks[(i+1)%NœÜ] (edge target).

Returns

  • paths (list) ‚Äì List of npoints x 2 path data for each connected component

  • chains (list) ‚Äì Chained node-information in format of (iphi,ipeak)

lgcpspatial.heading.link_peaks(peaks, maxd, max_end_distance=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Cleans up the result from match_peaks(), removing any peaks that aren‚Äôt tracked unambiguously over a range of heading angles.

Parameters

  • peaks (list) ‚Äì List of 2√óNPEAKS arrays containing (x,y) locations of identified peaks over a range of heading angles.

  • maxd (int) ‚Äì Maximum distance permitted between connected peaks at adjacent angles.

  • max_end_distance (float) ‚Äì Maximum distance allowed between endpoints of a tracked peak.

Returns

edges ‚Äì A graph connecting peaks putatively associated with the same grid field at different heading angles. This has the same length as the heading_angles argument. The format is the same as the result returned by match_peaks, but edges from peaks that aren‚Äôt tracked unambiguously over a range of heading angles have been removed.

Return type

list

lgcpspatial.heading.plot_tracked_peaks(peaks, edges, perim=None, compass=True, color=<matplotlib.colors.LinearSegmentedColormap object>, **kwargs)[source]ÔÉÅ

Plot connected grid fields. Use this with get_peaks_at_heading_angles() and link_peaks().

Assumptions: Orient Cartesian (x,y) plane in the standard way, with +y upwards and +x rightwards. Then heading angles are:

  • 0 : rightwards (eastwards)

  • ¬ΩœÄ : upwards (northwards)

  • œÄ : leftwards (westwards)

  • 3œÄ/2: downwards (southwards)

This assumes that peaks and edges are both taken from angles samples on [0,2œÄ), where the angles are linspace(0,2*pi,len(peaks)+1)[:-1].

Parameters

  • peaks (list) ‚Äì Length NANGLES list of 2xNPEAKS np.float32 arrays containing (rx,ry) peak locations at a list of heading angles, as returned by get_peaks_at_heading_angles().

  • edges (list) ‚Äì Length NANGLES list of edge sets for each pair of headings, as returned by match_peaks or link_peaks(). Each list entry is a 2√óNEDGES int32 array. This contains pairs of indecies (a,b). For edge set i, index a is the index into peaks[i] (edge source) and index b is the index into peaks[(i+1)%NœÜ] (edge target).

  • perim (np.float32) ‚Äì NPOINTS x 2 Array of (x,y) points of the arena perimeter to add to plot. Optional, default is None.

  • compass (bool) ‚Äì Draw colored compass rose if true

  • color (matplotlib color) ‚Äì Color or colormap to use for heading angles defaults to the custom riley circular color map.

  • **kwargs ‚Äì Forwarded to plot()

lgcpspatial.heading.locate_opposites(peaks, maxd, starti, edges)[source]ÔÉÅ

To be used on the result of calling match_peaks()

### Algorithm:

  • We have a list of edges between adjacent angles

  • Starting from a seed, follow the graph in both directions half-way around

  • Hopefully, we‚Äôll come to a peak from the opposite heading direction

Parameters

  • peaks (list) ‚Äì List of 2√óNPEAKS float32 arrays containing (x,y) locations of peaks at each of the angles specified by the list of heading angles heading_angles.

  • maxd ‚Äì The maximum distance between peaks allowed when connecting them

  • starti ‚Äì The angle (index) to start at as a ‚Äúseed‚Äù.

  • edges (returned by match_peaks(NœÜ,q,maxd)) ‚Äì lenghth NœÜ list of 2√óNCONNECTED edge sets containing indecies into the point sets (source) and targets in the next adjacent direction

Returns

  • iop (int) ‚Äì Index between 0 and NœÜ-1 into the q list of the opposite-heading fields

  • op (int32) ‚Äì Indecies of matching field in direction q[iop] for each field q[istart]. If no match exists, -1

  • dd (float32) ‚Äì Distance to matched peak, or NaN it not matched.

lgcpspatial.heading.plot_connection_arrow(q1, q2, op=None, **kwargs)[source]ÔÉÅ

Draw arrows connecting related fields from two maps.

Parameters

  • op (for every index in q1, corresponding index in q2) ‚Äì or -1 if no connection

  • q1 (field centers in map 1 (as x+iy complex numbers)) ‚Äì

  • q2 (field centers in map 2 (as x+iy complex numbers)) ‚Äì

lgcpspatial.heading.fit_heading_variance(data, model, Œ∏, NSEW)[source]ÔÉÅ

Re-optimize the prior marginal variance for the given set of heading-weighted models.

This is necessary for achieving interpretable posterior confidence intervals, since variable amounts (generally, less) of data are present for the different directions.

Parameters

  • data (Dataset) ‚Äì

  • model (Model) ‚Äì

  • Œ∏ (np.float32) ‚Äì Heading angles for every time sample in Dataset

  • NSEW (np.float32) ‚Äì List of reference heading angles to recompute

Returns

  • models (list) ‚Äì A list, the same length as NSEW, containing the models with optimized hyperparameters for each heading angle in NSEW

  • fits (list) ‚Äì A list, the same length as NSEW, containing the (posterior_mean, posterior_variance, loss) tuple returned by coordinate_descent for optimizing the model for each heading angle in NSEW.

lgcpspatial.heading.matched_cardinal_points(peaks, edges, indexNSEW)[source]ÔÉÅ

For each connected component from tracking peaks over various heading angles, return the z+iy location of all NSEW-facing points

Parameters

  • peaks (length N_HEADING_ANGLES list) ‚Äì List of peak locations from get_peaks_at_heading_angles

  • edges (length N_HEADING_ANGLES list) ‚Äì List of edges between peaks returned by match_peaks or link_peaks

  • indexNSEW (list) ‚Äì list of indecies into peaks and edges for the directions of interest (presumed to be N,S,E,W).

Returns

points ‚Äì A N_COMPONENTS x len(indexNSEW) array which identifies which of the peaks at these heading indecies are part of the same grid field. Reach row is a list of integer indecies into the corresponding list in the peaks variable for the heading-angle-indecies specified by indexNSEW.

Return type

np.array

lgcpspatial.heading.sample_heading_angles(data, models, fits, angles, exclusion_radius=None, edge_radius=None, nsamples=2000, resolution=2, height_threshold=0.8, prpeak_threshold=0.8, doplot=True, names=None, colors=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Performed a detailed analysis of a range of heading angles.

Apply this to the lists`models` and fits returned by fit_heading_variance(data,model,heading,angles).

This routine re-optimizes the kernel parameters via grid-search for each heading angle, and calculates posterior confidence intervals via sampling.

Parameters

  • data (Dataset) ‚Äì

  • models (list) ‚Äì List of N Models

  • fits (list) ‚Äì List of N fits returned by coordinate_descent

  • angles (list of floats) ‚Äì List of heading directions for each model

  • exclusion_radius (positive float) ‚Äì Region a peak must clear to be a local maximum, In units of pixels in the L√óL grid. If None, defaults to models[0].P/2.5.

  • edge_radius (positive float) ‚Äì Remove peaks closer than edge_radius bins to the arena‚Äôs edge. The default value of 0 does not remove points within a margin of the boundary. In units of pixels in the L√óL grid. If None, defaults to models[0].P/2.0.

  • nsamples (positive int) ‚Äì Number of posterior samples to use

  • resolution (positive int; default 2) ‚Äì Upsampling factor for posterior sampling

  • height_threshold (positive float ‚àà[0,1]) ‚Äì Fraction of locations a peak must be taller than to be included

  • prpeak_threshold (positive float ‚àà[0,1]) ‚Äì Fraction of samples a grid field must be present in to be included

  • doplot (boolean; default True) ‚Äì Whether to draw plots

  • names (list of str) ‚Äì Titles of each plot

  • colors (lost of Matplotlib colors) ‚Äì List of plotting colors for each heading angle
